questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A sesamoid bone The fabella is a sesamoid bone, which is a bone embedded within a tendon or a joint capsule. It is most commonly found in the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle in the knee. As a sesamoid bone, the fabella serves to protect tendons from stress and improve the mechanical efficiency of the joint. While the fabella is not present in all individuals, it is a normal anatomical variant found in some people. Incorrect Responses: (A) Same as fibula The fibula is one of the two long bones located in the lower leg, alongside the tibia. It is significantly larger than the fabella and serves a different purpose, providing support to the tibia and serving as an attachment point for muscles. The fabella is a small, accessory bone in the knee joint and is not the same as the fibula. Therefore, this option is incorrect. (B) An accessory projection from fibula While the fibula is involved in the lower limb's structural support, the fabella does not project from the fibula. Instead, it is a separate, small sesamoid bone found within the tendon of the gastrocnemius muscle near the knee. Therefore, this option is incorrect because the fabella is not a projection of the fibula. (D) None of the above Since option (C) is correct, this option is incorrect. The fabella is indeed a sesamoid bone, and therefore, "None of the above"

Correct Answer (B) Gastrocnemius lateral head. The fabella is a small sesamoid bone that is found within the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle. It is located posteriorly in the knee joint and is more commonly observed in humans as a normal anatomical variation. The fabella is thought to play a role in reducing friction and enhancing the mechanical efficiency of the gastrocnemius muscle during movement. It is often visible on X-rays and can be mistaken for a fracture or other pathological conditions in imaging studies. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Gastrocnemius medial head: While the medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle is an integral part of the muscle, the fabella is not typically found in its tendon. The fabella specifically occurs in the lateral head of the gastrocnemius, which is anatomically distinct from the medial head. C. Tendo calcaneus: The tendo calcaneus (Achilles tendon) is the common tendon of the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles and inserts on the calcaneus (heel bone). It does not house sesamoid bones like the fabella. Instead, the fabella is situated in the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle, proximal to the knee joint. D. Soleus muscle: The soleus muscle is located deeper to the gastrocnemius and contributes to the tendo calcaneus. It does not contain a sesamoid bone like the fabella. The fabella is specific to the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle.

questions.text: Muscles originating from ischial tuberosity are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Short head of biceps. The short head of the biceps femoris does not originate from the ischial tuberosity. Instead, it arises from the linea aspera of the femur. The short head of the biceps is distinct from the long head in that it is not involved in hip extension but rather only contributes to knee flexion and lateral rotation of the leg. The long head of the biceps femoris, in contrast, does originate from the ischial tuberosity, along with the other muscles listed in the options below. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. Adductor magnus: The adductor magnus has two parts, one of which (the hamstring part) originates from the ischial tuberosity. This muscle plays a role in adducting the thigh and assisting in hip extension, particularly when the hip is in a flexed position. C. Semimembranosus: The semimembranosus is part of the hamstring group of muscles and originates from the ischial tuberosity. It is involved in flexing the knee and extending the hip, as well as stabilizing the pelvis. D. Semitendinosus: The semitendinosus, another hamstring muscle, also originates from the ischial tuberosity. It is responsible for knee flexion and hip extension, as well as assisting in medial rotation of the knee when flexed.

questions.text: At the time of birth which of the following ossification centres are seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lower end of femur. At the time of birth, ossification centers are already visible in various parts of the skeletal system, but one of the first ossification centers to appear is at the lower end of the femur. This ossification center is typically seen around the time of birth and is essential for the development of the femur. The lower end of the femur (the distal femoral epiphysis) undergoes ossification early, marking an important stage in skeletal development in neonates. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. Upper end of humerus (Calcaneum): The upper end of the humerus and the calcaneum do not have ossification centers at birth. These areas begin ossifying a bit later in fetal development or shortly after birth. The upper end of the humerus, which forms the humeral head, begins ossification a few months after birth. The calcaneum (heel bone) also starts ossification during the fetal period but not at birth. C. Upper end of radius: The upper end of the radius (radial head) also does not have an ossification center at birth. Ossification begins in the radius after birth, typically around the first year of life. The radial head is one of the last bones in the forearm to ossify, with its ossification center appearing during infancy. D. Head of humerus: The head of the humerus has its ossification center appear a few months after birth, not at birth. At birth, the humeral head is still cartilaginous. Ossification of the head of the humerus is part of the normal developmental process and typically begins in infancy.

questions.text: All of the following muscles are composite muscle Except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A composite muscle is one that has two different functions or has multiple distinct parts that originate from different regions and perform different actions. A. Pectineus: This muscle is considered composite because it has both adductor and flexor functions. It is innervated by both the femoral nerve and the obturator nerve. C. Adductor magnus: This is also a composite muscle because it has two parts: the adductor part (innervated by the obturator nerve) and the hamstring part (innervated by the sciatic nerve). D. Biceps femoris: The biceps femoris has two heads, the long head (innervated by the sciatic nerve) and the short head (innervated by the common peroneal nerve), making it a composite muscle. B. Rectus femoris: This muscle is a single-function muscle primarily responsible for extending the knee. It is not considered composite because it does not have distinct parts that perform different functions or are innervated by different nerves.

questions.text: Muscle attached to lateral surface of greater trochanter
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gluteus medius. Explanation for the Correct Answer: The gluteus medius muscle is attached to the lateral surface of the greater trochanter of the femur. It is a major hip abductor and plays a key role in stabilizing the pelvis during walking and running. The gluteus medius muscle originates from the outer surface of the ilium and inserts on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter, making it the correct choice. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Gluteus maximus: This statement is incorrect. The gluteus maximus muscle attaches to the posterior surface of the greater trochanter, not the lateral surface. While the gluteus maximus is important for hip extension and outward rotation, its attachment is different from that of the gluteus medius. C. Gluteus minimus: This statement is incorrect. The gluteus minimus muscle attaches to the anterior surface of the greater trochanter, not the lateral surface. Like the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus helps in hip abduction, but its attachment is on a different part of the greater trochanter. D. Piriformis: This statement is incorrect. The piriformis muscle attaches to the anterior surface of the sacrum and the greater trochanter, but it inserts on the medial surface of the greater trochanter, not the lateral surface. It is responsible for lateral rotation and abduction of the hip when the hip is flexed.

questions.text: Lower end of femur is ossified from how many ossification centers
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1. Explanation for the Correct Answer: The lower end of the femur is ossified from one primary ossification center. The ossification of the femur occurs in a sequential manner, with one primary ossification center that forms the body of the femur, including the lower end. As a child grows, this ossification center extends to cover the distal femur, and later, secondary ossification centers develop in the epiphyses (for the femoral head, for example). However, the lower end of the femur, which includes the distal portion of the shaft and the condyles, is initially formed from a single ossification center. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: B. 2: This is incorrect because the lower end of the femur is not ossified from two separate centers. There is only one primary ossification center for the lower femur, though secondary ossification centers may appear later for the condyles. C. 3: This is incorrect because there are no three primary ossification centers in the lower end of the femur. The number of ossification centers increases with the development of secondary ossification centers, but initially, it is just one. D. 4: This is incorrect because four ossification centers do not contribute to the lower end of the femur. The number of ossification centers is not as many as four for the initial ossification of the distal femur.
